questions.question_text:
An architect is asked to analyze poor performance on a Horizon VDI environment and provide recommendations on how to improve the user experience.
The architect documents:
✑ An ESXi cluster of 4 nodes using vSAN
✑ Each node has 128GB of RAM, four 500GB 10K HDD, one 200GB SSD
✑ Each desktop is configured with 4GB of RAM and 2vCPUs
✑ Each desktop has a working set of 20 GB
✑ The environment peaks at 150 concurrent desktops in use
What action can the architect recommend?

choices.B: Add an additional 200GB SSD to each of the ESXi hosts.
choices.D: Increase the RAM assigned to the virtual desktops.
choices.C: Reserve all RAM assigned to the virtual desktops.
choices.A: Add three additional 200GB SSD drives to each of the ESXi hosts.

discussion.content:
The answer is A. Here is the reason:
Each vSAN node can have up to 5 disk groups, each one with 1 disk for cache and 7 disks for capacity.
As the scenario documents, there's only 1 disk group per host (because there is only one SSD drive in each host). This vSAN is hybrid (SSDs+HDDs). This disk group have 1 200GB SSD disk for cache and 4 500GB HDD disks for capacity. The cache disk must be at least 10% of the total capacity disks (which is the case). 
If you add 3 200GB SSD disk to each of the hosts, you can have 4 disk groups, each one with 1 200GB SSD disk for cache and 1 500GB for capacity, augmenting considerably the cache, improving the performance and the user experience.
We could consider the second alternative (B), adding 1 200GB SSD to each of the hosts. So, we could have 2 disk groups in each host, each disk group with 1 200GB SSD disk and 2 500GB HDD disks. It would be a cheaper solution, but performance would not be as good as the first alternative. It would be a cheaper solution, but performance would not be as good as the first alternative. However, the scenario has no budgetary restrictions.
The first solution is more expensive, but more performant. Price is what you pay, value is what you get...
By adding one SSD to every Host, it can be used as RAM/memory host extension.

The answer is A. Based on this vSAN sizing doc: https://storagehub.vmware.com/t/vmware-r-vsan-tm-design-and-sizing-guide-2/cache-sizing-overview-1/

The key is we are given the working set: 20 GB
Currently, the VSan Cacheis only 800 GB (4 Nodes @ 200 GB each)
Total working set is 3000 GB (150 desktops * 20 GB Working Set) 

In order to achieve the right sizing, we need 3 new SSDs on each node (800 GB per Node * 4 Nodes is 3200 GB)

A company's IT team wants to provide multiple Microsoft Office suite applications to end users without incurring any Windows desktop operating system licensing fees.
They also want each end users' Microsoft Office suite application customization settings and configuration changes preserved and restored when the end user logs off and logs back in.
Which two VMware technologies must they deploy to meet the requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I'm choosing CD. You need a Windows OS for Writable volumes so Application pools are needed but also UEM over Identity Manager as the clients can access via the Horizon Client

CD
RDSH to avoid MS VDA licensing. UEM to persist settings. AppVol don't work with RDS. UEM is also more granular on persisting settings.

C + E
Can only be Appl.pools + UEM. Appl.pools because any form of Win10 Desktop requires licenses which the customer does not want. So only RDSH as a basis remains. The second part must be UEM because writeable-volumes on RDSH is not possible.
DE... AppVols & UEM

choices.C: Deploy View Security Server. Configure it to only allow domain joined computers accessing Horizon.
choices.A: Deploy NSX. Use NSX feature to validate client's MAC addresses and only allow registered clients.
choices.B: Deploy VMware Identity Manager. Configure it to require RSA SecureID. Only install the RSA SecureID soft token software on managed devices. Configure Horizon to allow SAML.
choices.D: Deploy Unified Access Gateway. Configure it to require a device client certificate and to use pass-through authentication for Horizon. Distribute certificates to managed devices.
